Alexandre,

In contrast to your stated position regarding applicability of =
EA to 
robotics and control, the following book unifies AI, engineering 
op=
timization/search, and control theory:

"Biomimicry for optimization, contr=
ol, and automation", by Passino, 
Kevin M. ( http://www.ece.osu.edu/~passin=
o ), "The background of the 
author is control science, theory, engineering=
, and practice (and 
hence, physics, differential equations, system theory,=
 stability 
theory, optimization theory, stochastic processes, etc.)..."

I=
t is a refreshing practical perspective that leverages the best that 
each =
field has to offer from a global perspective, without getting 
fixated on a=
ny given pet approach.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Alexandre Devert <marm=
akoide@...> wrote:
>
> Hi
> 
>   I'am also quite sceptical about using EC a=
nd a pure
> neural networks architecture to control a robot in
> such a goo=
d way. 
> 
>   1) Optimizing control parameters by using a solid
> physics =
simulation
>     - Those simulations are slow, not accurate, prone
> to num=
erical instabilities, not the good candidate for
> stochastic optimizers
> =
    - Going from simulation to reality is hard.
>     - There is a boostrap=
ing problems : as instance
> for 2 legs robots, a random set of parameters =
are
> likely to make the robot falling and miserably
> crawling on the floo=
r.
>     - Any works on EC and robotics provides guarantee
> on the optimiz=
ed controlers. Optimal control theory
> guys can do that.
>     - People th=
at are doing real robots don't believe
> in it at all
> 
>   2) Optimizing =
control parameters on the real
> hardware
>     - 100000 fitness evaluation=
s ? Expensive robot ?
> If the evaluations are local to an engine behavior =
and
> a 1 sec time frame, no problem, you got plenty of
> evaluations. If t=
he fitness is the global robot
> behavior on a time frame of 10 minutes, ju=
st forget
> about it. Optimal control theory guys can optimize
> their 2 or=
 3 parameters with a quadratic problem
> solver in minutes.
>     - Stochas=
tic search on real robot to improve that
> very same robot behavior imply r=
andom try : "Ok, let's
> try moving close to that cliff..."
> 
> Alex,
>
